title: John Lewis Partnership warns of lower profits on pension charges
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Sep 10, 2015, 10:10 BST - UK Markets close in 6 hrs 20 mins John Lewis Partnership warns of lower profits on pension charges By Ashley Armstrong | Telegraph – 32 minutes ago 111.60 +17.05 
The owner of department stores and Waitrose reports that higher pension charges have dragged profits 26pc lower in the first half of the year 
John Lewis Partnership has said that warned that its full-year profits could fall by as much as a fifth on the back of higher pensions costs and a tougher trading environment. 
The partnership, which includes the John Lewis department stores and Waitrose food business, said that half-year pre-tax profits before exceptional items had fallen by 26pc to £96.7m. 
Including £128m of proceeds from the sale of its Clearings storage depot in Chelsea, West London, and other one-offs, JLP said that pre-tax profits rose by £72.6m to £224m. 
However it warned that even a strong performance over the next six months would be unlikely to offset a £60m increase in full-year pension charges. 
As a result, the retail group said that pre-tax profits before staff bonuses and exceptional items for the full year would be between £270m and £320m, compared to £341.6m a year ago. 
Sir Charlie Mayfield, chairman of John Lewis Partnership, said that excluding the higher pension charges trading levels at the retailer were “broadly level with last year despite the turmoil in the grocery market”. 
Overall JLP revenues grew by 1.9pc to £4.5bn. 
Waitrose said that gross sales for the first half grew by 1.1pc to £3.18bn but on a like-for-like basis this was down by 1.3pc. The food business said that it had attracted 280,000 more customer transactions each week during the past six months compared to last year, which had helped its market share to grow to 5.1pc. 
The food retailer, which launched a “pick your own offer promotion” in June, said that 700,000 customers had taken part in the scheme, which gives them 20pc discounts on 10 products of their choosing. 
Waitrose said that this approach had meant it had achieved sustainable sales growth rather than “joining the industry in across-the-board price cutting aimed at driving volume in the short term”. 
Waitrose also said that its click and collect orders had grown by 50pc. 
John Lewis said that it had outperformed the industry’s high street sales average with a 3pc like-for-like increase in sales and gross sales of £1.94bn. 
The retailer said that its department store fashion sales were a “standout”, posting a 7.5pc increase while sales of its homewares were 4.9pc higher. The retailer, which has just modernised its home department in its Oxford Street flagship store at a cost of £14m, said that this was a “good performance against the impact of the general election and a late start to summer sales”. John Lewis’ home division was helped by a 33.5pc rise in sales of outdoor living goods, such as hammocks and barbecues. 
However, the retailer reported a 0.7pc slide in its electrical sales against the previous year after being hit by a lack of new product launches. John Lewis, which is facing stiff competition from beefed-up Dixons Carphone (Stuttgart: CWB.SG - news ) , said that it had secured the rights to sell Apple (Swiss: AAPL.SW - news ) Watches in shops, which would give it “more momentum in technology sales for the second half”. 
The group said that its online sales grew by 17.1pc to £647m, although this does not include returned items to shops. 
“This has been a solid first half for the Partnership in a difficult market. Both Waitrose and John Lewis are growing sales and increasing market share,” said Sir Charlie. 
“Conditions in the market will remain difficult, especially in grocery where there is little sign of any price inflation. However, I expect sales in both Waitrose and John Lewis to perform comparatively well against the market, helped by promising new ranges and online capability.”
